title: Ticket #3854: Failure to detect OpSys versions
description:
HTCondor attempts to automatically detect the Linux distribution and version so that it can correctly set a bunch of machine ad attributes.

Unfortunately, it does so in an unreliable manner. Specifically, it parses the file /etc/issue. We should do better, as often times sysadmin will customize the contents of /etc/issue or delete it entirely, as this file is displayed before the login prompt. Currently half the systems we use on the Open Science Grid have removed or customized /etc/issue.
remarks:
2013-Aug-14 14:58:14 by tannenba:
On RedHat and Centos systems, it would be more reliable to look in /etc/redhat-release and then fall back to /etc/issue.

On Debian, look in /etc/debian_version for a number like 6.0.7 or 7.1, although on older Ubuntu systems this file contains a string of the release code name instead of a number.

The ultimate is to run lsb_release -d. If the system is LSB compliant, this gives exactly what we want. Seems like everything RHEL 5.6 and newer has this. Downside is RHEL 5.0 does not. Also a downside is the need to fork and exec a shell script everytime condor_config() is invoked; this seems really expensive. Perhaps the condor_master should run lsb_release -d and store the result in a file in $(LOG); everything else would look for this file before anything else.

2013-Aug-14 15:04:39 by tim:
Debian also has an /etc/issue.net Here is a sample: Debian GNU/Linux 7

2013-Aug-14 16:16:34 by tannenba:
If /etc/issue has been removed or mangled, it is likely that /etc/issue.net has been mangled as well. Only difference is the first is displayed before local logins, the latter before remote logins. But hey, maybe worth trying.
